subject: RE: Mocking libraries and moving parts (was: Re: [junit] unit tes t       case for login())
msgSnippet: Yes I m aware that the various mocking frameworks all provide ways to in erffect provide stub implementations of a given interface. The problerm is having to
messageBody:
Yes I'm aware that the various mocking frameworks all provide ways to in
erffect provide stub implementations of a given interface. The problerm is
having to provide the interelationships between the various interfaces to
allow the mock to function adequately. In the simple example below I needed
to provide a mock IDfSession with enough extra code for it to produce mock
IDfGroup and IDfUser objects that could then be resolved against each other
in several variations by the business logic. It was a major effort just to
get the mocks set up. IIRC the test code was significantly larger than the
original class, let alone just the method I was testing.

The fact that calls to Documentum super class methods are intermingled with
business logic to a high degree and seperating them would complicate the
class inordinately making it less maintainable is also annoying.

Having said that I still haven't given up, I'm just less confident than I
was. I also reread the holy books regularly ("Refactoring", "Working
Effectively With Legacy Code", "JUnit Recipes", "Design Patterns" and
"Refactoring to Patterns") trying to get ideas :-)

Michael Rutherfurd


-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Wednesday, 21 June 2006 7:21 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: Mocking libraries and moving parts (was: Re: [junit] unit tes t
case for login())



Rutherford, Michael wrote:
> In one example I tried was a fairly simple piece of business logic. I
needed
> to write some tests around a user belonging to a group.
>
> I needed at a minimum an implementation of IDfUser and IDfGroup. Due to
the
> nature of the beast it is most common to get these from the session
> (IDfSession). As all of these are interfaces it wasn't too bad but each of
> the interfaces extends others and have several hundred methods each. I
> eventually decided that what I was trying to test in this case was
> Documentum logic and that I should just trust the framework.
>
One quick point: a major appeal of JMock, and the other mocking
frameworks, as far as I know, is that the number of methods or
superinterfaces of an interface does not affect the complexity of the
test, just the number of methods used. However, I also agree that you
shouldn't test the framework, just your own code, as much as possible.
Thanks for the clarification,

David Saff
